title: Genesis Chapter 47 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Genesis chapter 47 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Genesis Chapter 47 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Genesis Chapter 47.

questions.question: Where did Joseph say his father and brethren were dwelling?
options: Land of Goshen
Land of Canaan
Land of Egypt
Land of Rameses
questions.correctAnswer: Land of Goshen
questions.explanation: Joseph told Pharaoh that his father and brethren were in the land of Goshen, according to Genesis 47:1.

questions.question: How many of Joseph's brethren did he present to Pharaoh?
options: Five men
Seven men
Twelve men
Three men
questions.correctAnswer: Five men
questions.explanation: Joseph took five of his brethren and presented them unto Pharaoh as stated in Genesis 47:2.

questions.question: What occupation did Joseph's brethren tell Pharaoh they had?
options: Shepherds
Farmers
Merchants
Fishermen
questions.correctAnswer: Shepherds
questions.explanation: Joseph's brethren said to Pharaoh that they and their fathers were shepherds, according to Genesis 47:3.

questions.question: Why did Joseph's brethren request to dwell in the land of Goshen?
options: Because of famine and no pasture in Canaan
Because Pharaoh commanded it
Because Goshen was their inheritance
Because they wanted to be near Pharaoh
questions.correctAnswer: Because of famine and no pasture in Canaan
questions.explanation: They asked to dwell in Goshen because there was no pasture for their flocks in Canaan due to the famine, as stated in Genesis 47:4.

questions.question: What did Pharaoh say about where Joseph's father and brethren should dwell?
options: In the land of Goshen, the best of the land
In the desert outside Egypt
In the city of Rameses only
Anywhere except Goshen
questions.correctAnswer: In the land of Goshen, the best of the land
questions.explanation: Pharaoh told Joseph to let his father and brethren dwell in the best of the land, in Goshen, as found in Genesis 47:6.

questions.question: How old did Jacob say he was when Pharaoh asked?
options: One hundred and thirty years
One hundred years
Ninety years
One hundred and forty years
questions.correctAnswer: One hundred and thirty years
questions.explanation: Jacob stated that he was 130 years old when Pharaoh asked his age, according to Genesis 47:9.

questions.question: In which land did Joseph give his father and brethren possession?
options: Land of Rameses
Land of Goshen
Land of Canaan
Land of Egypt generally
questions.correctAnswer: Land of Rameses
questions.explanation: Joseph placed his father and brethren in the land of Rameses as Pharaoh commanded, per Genesis 47:11.

questions.question: What did Joseph do for his father and brethren during the famine?
options: Nourished them with bread according to their families
Sent them back to Canaan
Made them work in the fields
Gave them gold
questions.correctAnswer: Nourished them with bread according to their families
questions.explanation: Joseph nourished his father's household with bread during the famine, as written in Genesis 47:12.

questions.question: What happened when the money failed in Egypt and Canaan during the famine?
options: People gave their cattle in exchange for bread
People left Egypt
Pharaoh provided free food
Joseph stopped selling bread
questions.correctAnswer: People gave their cattle in exchange for bread
questions.explanation: When money failed, the Egyptians gave their cattle to Joseph for bread, according to Genesis 47:16 and Genesis 47:17.

questions.question: True or False: Joseph bought all the land of Egypt, including the priests' land, for Pharaoh.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joseph bought all the land except the priests' land, which they did not sell because they had a portion assigned by Pharaoh, as stated in Genesis 47:20 and Genesis 47:22.

questions.question: What portion of the produce were the people to give to Pharaoh according to Joseph's law?
options: One fifth
One fourth
One third
One half
questions.correctAnswer: One fifth
questions.explanation: Joseph made it a law that the people should give one-fifth of their produce to Pharaoh, as specified in Genesis 47:24 and Genesis 47:26.

questions.question: True or False: Israel lived in the land of Goshen and multiplied exceedingly.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:27 states that Israel dwelt in Goshen and grew and multiplied exceedingly.

questions.question: How many years did Jacob live in the land of Egypt before he died?
options: Seventeen years
Ten years
Twenty years
Thirty years
questions.correctAnswer: Seventeen years
questions.explanation: Jacob lived in Egypt for seventeen years before his death, as mentioned in Genesis 47:28.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'If now I have found grace in thy sight, put, I pray thee, thy hand under my _______'
options: thigh
hand
foot
heart
questions.correctAnswer: thigh
questions.explanation: Jacob asked Joseph to put his hand under his thigh as a sign of promise, according to Genesis 47:29.

questions.question: True or False: Joseph swore to bury Jacob in Egypt as he wished.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joseph promised to bury Jacob not in Egypt but in the buryingplace of his fathers, as found in Genesis 47:30.

medium.title: Genesis Chapter 47 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Genesis Chapter 47 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Genesis 47 teach us about trusting God during times of scarcity and famine?
options: By showing Joseph's wise management of resources and provision for his family
By telling the people to hoard food and keep it for themselves
By instructing the people to leave Egypt and seek food elsewhere
By encouraging immediate rebellion against Pharaoh's policies
questions.correctAnswer: By showing Joseph's wise management of resources and provision for his family
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:12-14 shows Joseph providing bread to his family and gathering money for corn, demonstrating faith and stewardship during famine. Verses 15-17 show his wisdom in exchanging cattle for bread, teaching trust in God's provision through wise management.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with contentment during hardship. Based on Genesis 47, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Contentment comes by trusting God's plan and being faithful in stewardship
Contentment means ignoring hardships and pretending all is well
Contentment requires demanding compensation from others
Contentment is achieved by isolating oneself
questions.correctAnswer: Contentment comes by trusting God's plan and being faithful in stewardship
questions.explanation: Jacob expresses humility and contentment in Genesis 47:9 about the days of his life, and Joseph’s management of resources (verses 23-24) demonstrates faithfulness and trust in God's provision. These passages encourage believers to trust God despite difficulties.

questions.question: How does Genesis 47 demonstrate the importance of obedience and honoring family responsibilities?
options: Joseph obeyed Pharaoh and cared for his family, ensuring their welfare in Egypt
Joseph ignored his family and focused only on Pharaoh
Joseph demanded payment from his family for living in Egypt
Joseph sent his family away to fend for themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph obeyed Pharaoh and cared for his family, ensuring their welfare in Egypt
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:5-6 and 11-12 show Joseph following Pharaoh’s command and providing for his father Jacob and brothers, exemplifying obedience and family responsibility. This teaches believers to honor and care for their families.

questions.question: How does Genesis 47 teach about humility and respect in relationships with authority?
options: Jacob humbly blesses Pharaoh and respects his authority
Jacob demands equal status with Pharaoh
Jacob disregards Pharaoh’s questions
Jacob refuses to meet Pharaoh
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob humbly blesses Pharaoh and respects his authority
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:7-10 records Jacob blessing Pharaoh and humbly answering his question about his age. This models humility and respect toward those in authority as a biblical virtue.

questions.question: What does Genesis 47 teach about stewardship and generosity in times of crisis?
options: Joseph exchanges bread for money and cattle to sustain the people
Joseph hoards resources only for himself
Joseph refuses to help the people during famine
Joseph demands exorbitant prices for food
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph exchanges bread for money and cattle to sustain the people
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:14-17 describes Joseph gathering money and then taking cattle in exchange for bread, showing stewardship and generosity to preserve life during famine. It encourages believers to wisely share resources.

questions.question: A fellow believer is worried about losing possessions in hard times. According to Genesis 47, what biblical principle can you share?
options: Trust God’s provision and be willing to serve Him even if possessions are lost
Only rely on possessions for security
Avoid helping others to protect your own assets
Demand compensation for losses
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God’s provision and be willing to serve Him even if possessions are lost
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:18-25 shows Egyptians selling land and becoming servants to Pharaoh out of necessity, yet they acknowledge Joseph saved their lives. This teaches trust in God and humility in hardship.

questions.question: True or False: Genesis 47 shows that Joseph made a law requiring all Egyptians to give a fifth of their produce to Pharaoh, except the priests.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:23-26 states Joseph established a law that a fifth of the produce belonged to Pharaoh, except for the priests’ lands, teaching biblical principles of stewardship and governance.

questions.question: True or False: According to Genesis 47, Jacob desired to be buried in Egypt with his fathers.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:29-30 records Jacob asking Joseph to bury him not in Egypt but with his fathers, showing the importance of honoring family heritage and God’s promises.

questions.question: How does Genesis 47 illustrate the virtue of perseverance through trials?
options: Joseph patiently manages famine relief and maintains hope for his family
Joseph gives up when famine is severe
Joseph ignores the famine and focuses only on Pharaoh’s commands
Joseph blames others for the crisis
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph patiently manages famine relief and maintains hope for his family
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:13-17 shows Joseph’s faithful management through famine, providing sustenance despite difficulties, teaching perseverance and trust in God.

questions.question: Based on Genesis 47, what is a biblical response to asking for help during difficult times?
options: Approach with humility and honesty about needs
Demand help aggressively without respect
Hide needs and refuse to ask
Blame others for the situation
questions.correctAnswer: Approach with humility and honesty about needs
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:18 shows people honestly confessing their lack of money and resources to Joseph, demonstrating humility and trust in God’s provision through others.

questions.question: How does the passage teach about honoring parental requests and legacy?
options: Joseph promises to fulfill Jacob’s burial wishes outside Egypt
Joseph ignores his father’s requests
Joseph plans to bury Jacob in Egypt against his will
Joseph delays addressing his father’s wishes
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph promises to fulfill Jacob’s burial wishes outside Egypt
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:29-31 records Joseph promising to bury Jacob with his ancestors, showing respect for parental legacy and honoring family requests.

questions.question: How does Genesis 47 encourage believers to serve others during times of difficulty?
options: Joseph feeds many with bread despite famine and manages resources for the good of all
Joseph isolates himself and refuses to share
Joseph only helps Pharaoh’s family
Joseph charges excessive prices to the needy
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph feeds many with bread despite famine and manages resources for the good of all
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:12-17 shows Joseph providing bread to his family and the Egyptians, demonstrating selfless service and stewardship.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Genesis 47 teaches that when the Egyptians had no money left, Joseph asked them to give him their ______ in exchange for bread.
options: cattle
gold
houses
lands
questions.correctAnswer: cattle
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:16 states Joseph said, 'Give your cattle; and I will give you for your cattle, if money fail,' teaching trust and stewardship during crisis.

questions.question: How does Genesis 47 teach about the role of work and productivity in family and community life?
options: Joseph provides seed and encourages the people to sow the land and give a fifth to Pharaoh
Joseph discourages work and relies only on charity
Joseph forbids the people to plant crops
Joseph takes all produce without return
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph provides seed and encourages the people to sow the land and give a fifth to Pharaoh
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:23-24 records Joseph giving seed to the people and setting a system of tithing, encouraging productive work and careful stewardship.

questions.question: What does Genesis 47 teach about family unity during hardship?
options: Joseph brings his family to dwell together in Goshen and provides for them
Joseph separates from his family
Joseph leaves his family to fend for themselves
Joseph blames his family for the famine
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph brings his family to dwell together in Goshen and provides for them
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:1-6 and 27 show Joseph bringing his family to Goshen and ensuring their well-being, modeling family unity and care during trials.

questions.question: How does Genesis 47 demonstrate the importance of integrity in leadership?
options: Joseph honestly manages resources and establishes just laws for the land
Joseph takes advantage of the people for personal gain
Joseph hides the famine from Pharaoh
Joseph ignores the needs of the people
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph honestly manages resources and establishes just laws for the land
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:23-26 shows Joseph making laws for fair taxation and managing famine relief transparently, teaching integrity in leadership.

hard.title: Genesis Chapter 47 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Genesis Chapter 47.

questions.question: In Genesis 47:3, what occupation do Joseph's brothers tell Pharaoh they and their fathers have?
options: Shepherds
Farmers
Merchants
Soldiers
questions.correctAnswer: Shepherds
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:3 states that Joseph's brothers told Pharaoh, 'Thy servants are shepherds, both we, and also our fathers.' This identifies their occupation directly.

questions.question: What is the significance of the land of Goshen in Genesis 47:6 in relation to Joseph's brothers?
options: It was the best land in Egypt for shepherding
It was a desert land unsuitable for farming
It was the capital city of Egypt
It was the land given to the priests
questions.correctAnswer: It was the best land in Egypt for shepherding
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:6 shows Pharaoh telling Joseph to settle his family in Goshen, which was suitable for their occupation as shepherds, indicating the land's fertility and appropriateness for livestock.

questions.question: How old was Jacob when he spoke to Pharaoh, according to Genesis 47:9?
options: 130 years
120 years
147 years
100 years
questions.correctAnswer: 130 years
questions.explanation: Jacob states in Genesis 47:9 that 'The days of the years of my pilgrimage are an hundred and thirty years.'

questions.question: What economic strategy did Joseph implement in Egypt during the famine as described in Genesis 47:14-20?
options: He gathered all money and then exchanged cattle for bread, eventually acquiring all land for Pharaoh
He distributed grain freely among the people without payment
He imported food from neighboring countries
He raised taxes on all goods except grain
questions.correctAnswer: He gathered all money and then exchanged cattle for bread, eventually acquiring all land for Pharaoh
questions.explanation: The passage from Genesis 47:14-20 describes Joseph collecting money for grain, then exchanging cattle for bread when money was gone, and finally buying all land for Pharaoh because of the famine-induced sales.

questions.question: Which group was exempt from selling their land to Pharaoh according to Genesis 47:22?
options: Priests
Joseph's family
Foreigners
Military officials
questions.correctAnswer: Priests
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:22 states that Joseph did not buy the land of the priests because they had an assigned portion from Pharaoh and did not sell their lands.

questions.question: According to Genesis 47:24, what portion of their produce were the Egyptians required to give to Pharaoh?
options: One fifth
One third
Half
One tenth
questions.correctAnswer: One fifth
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:24 specifies that the people must give a fifth part of the produce to Pharaoh, keeping four parts for themselves.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of Jacob blessing Pharaoh in Genesis 47:7-10?
options: It foreshadows the rise of Israel in a foreign land and shows Jacob's recognition of God's sovereignty over Egypt
It establishes an Egyptian priesthood
It indicates Jacob's submission to Egyptian gods
It marks the end of the covenant with Abraham
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the rise of Israel in a foreign land and shows Jacob's recognition of God's sovereignty over Egypt
questions.explanation: Jacob blessing Pharaoh (Genesis 47:7-10) signifies recognition of divine providence and foreshadows Israel's growth in Egypt under God's plan.

questions.question: What does the Hebrew term translated as 'sojourn' in Genesis 47:4 imply about the Israelites' stay in Egypt?
options: Temporary residence without permanent settlement
Permanent conquest and settlement
Exile with no hope of return
Religious pilgrimage
questions.correctAnswer: Temporary residence without permanent settlement
questions.explanation: The term 'sojourn' in Genesis 47:4 implies a temporary stay, consistent with the Israelites' initial intention to live in Egypt only for a time.

questions.question: How does Joseph's acquisition of land for Pharaoh in Genesis 47:20 reflect ancient Near Eastern economic practices during famine?
options: It mirrors practices where rulers consolidated land to maintain control during scarcity
It was unique and unprecedented in the Near East
It was a form of voluntary land donation by peasants
It was a punishment for the Egyptians' disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: It mirrors practices where rulers consolidated land to maintain control during scarcity
questions.explanation: In Genesis 47:20, Joseph's buying of all land for Pharaoh reflects known ancient Near Eastern customs where rulers gained land rights during famine to centralize power and resource distribution.

questions.question: True or False: According to Genesis 47:27, Israel prospered and multiplied exceedingly in the land of Goshen.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:27 states explicitly that Israel dwelt in Goshen, possessed land, and multiplied exceedingly, confirming their prosperity.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jacob’s request to Joseph regarding his burial in Genesis 47:29-30?
options: It reflects the patriarchal hope to be buried with ancestors, affirming covenantal promises
It shows Jacob's rejection of Egyptian customs
It indicates Joseph's future role as a political leader
It reveals a prophetic vision about the Exodus
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the patriarchal hope to be buried with ancestors, affirming covenantal promises
questions.explanation: Jacob's request to be buried in the ancestral burial place (Genesis 47:29-30) reaffirms his connection to the covenant land and promises made to his forefathers.

questions.question: Which literary device is evident in the structure of Genesis 47 with the focus on famine, provision, and settlement?
options: Chiasm emphasizing famine and blessing
Allegory of Egypt as Egypt
Parable of the Good Shepherd
Typology of the Exodus
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm emphasizing famine and blessing
questions.explanation: Genesis 47 exhibits a chiastic structure centering on famine hardship and divine provision through Joseph, reflecting a literary device common in Hebrew narrative.

questions.question: How does Joseph’s negotiation of land and resources in Genesis 47 anticipate the later enslavement of Israel in Egypt?
options: By centralizing power under Pharaoh and reducing the people to servants, foreshadowing bondage
By ensuring permanent freedom for Israelites
By establishing Israel as Egyptian priests
By dividing the land equally among tribes
questions.correctAnswer: By centralizing power under Pharaoh and reducing the people to servants, foreshadowing bondage
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:18-26 shows Joseph buying land and people becoming servants to Pharaoh, a foreshadowing of Israel's later enslavement as described in Exodus.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'put thy hand under my thigh' in Genesis 47:29 signify in the ancient Near Eastern cultural context?
options: A solemn oath binding future agreement
A casual greeting
A gesture of disrespect
A ritual of sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: A solemn oath binding future agreement
questions.explanation: In Genesis 47:29, the phrase indicates a serious oath in ancient Near Eastern culture, signifying a binding promise.

questions.question: What role does Joseph play in Genesis 47 that echoes a type of a savior figure in biblical theology?
options: He provides sustenance and security during famine, prefiguring messianic provision
He becomes king of Egypt
He leads a military campaign
He institutes a new religion
correctAnswer
questions.explanation: Joseph's role as the provider of bread during famine echoes the role of a savior figure, pointing to Christ who is the Bread of Life sustaining His people.

theological.title: Genesis Chapter 47 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Genesis Chapter 47 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What reason did Joseph's brothers give Pharaoh for seeking to dwell in the land of Goshen?
options: They were shepherds and needed pasture for their flocks due to famine in Canaan
They wanted to serve Pharaoh directly in his court
They sought to establish a new kingdom
They were escaping political persecution
questions.correctAnswer: They were shepherds and needed pasture for their flocks due to famine in Canaan
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:3-4 states that Joseph's brothers told Pharaoh they were shepherds and came to sojourn because there was no pasture in Canaan due to famine. This reflects the biblical theme of God’s providence in times of trial (Psalm 23:1-2; John 10:11).

questions.question: How did Pharaoh respond to Joseph's request concerning his family’s dwelling place?
options: He granted them to dwell in the land of Goshen and offered leadership roles if able
He refused and sent them back to Canaan
He made them slaves immediately
He placed them under strict surveillance
questions.correctAnswer: He granted them to dwell in the land of Goshen and offered leadership roles if able
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:6 shows Pharaoh allowing Joseph to settle his father and brothers in Goshen and even to appoint active men as overseers. This demonstrates God’s sovereign provision through human authority (Romans 13:1; Daniel 2:21).

questions.question: What was Jacob’s assessment of the length and quality of his life when speaking to Pharaoh?
options: Few and evil have been the days of my pilgrimage, not reaching the lifespan of my fathers
My life has been long and prosperous beyond measure
I have lived exactly as long as my ancestors
My days have been filled with joy and abundance
questions.correctAnswer: Few and evil have been the days of my pilgrimage, not reaching the lifespan of my fathers
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:9 shows Jacob reflecting on the brevity and hardship of his life, a theological acknowledgment of human mortality and the fallen state of the world (Psalm 90:10; Ecclesiastes 3:1-2; James 4:14).

questions.question: How did Joseph sustain the people during the famine after the money in the land was exhausted?
options: He exchanged bread for their cattle
He gave them bread for free
He asked them to leave Egypt
He requested gold and silver instead
questions.correctAnswer: He exchanged bread for their cattle
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:16-17 reveals Joseph's economic strategy during famine, exchanging food for livestock, illustrating God’s provision and the stewardship of resources (Matthew 25:14-30; Philippians 4:19).

questions.question: What significant action did Joseph take concerning the land of Egypt during the famine?
options: He bought all the land for Pharaoh except the priests’ land
He distributed the land equally among the poor
He sold his own property to help the people
He commanded the people to abandon their land
questions.correctAnswer: He bought all the land for Pharaoh except the priests’ land
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:20-22 shows Joseph consolidating land ownership under Pharaoh’s control, except for the priests’, highlighting God's sovereign governance and foreshadowing messianic themes of divine kingship (Psalm 24:1; Isaiah 61:4; Revelation 11:15).

questions.question: What proportion of the harvest were the Egyptians required to give to Pharaoh after the famine?
options: One fifth (20%)
One half (50%)
One tenth (10%)
Three quarters (75%)
questions.correctAnswer: One fifth (20%)
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:24 and 26 establish that Pharaoh would receive a fifth of the produce, a system instituted by Joseph. This parallels the biblical tithe and offerings, underscoring God’s provision and human responsibility (Leviticus 27:30; Malachi 3:10; Hebrews 7:2).

questions.question: Why was the land of the priests not sold to Pharaoh during the famine?
options: Because the priests had a portion assigned by Pharaoh and ate from it
Because the priests refused to sell their land
Because the priests were exempt by divine law
Because the priests had no land to sell
questions.correctAnswer: Because the priests had a portion assigned by Pharaoh and ate from it
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:22 explains that priests' lands were exempt since Pharaoh provided for them, reflecting the special priestly role and sustenance in Israelite and Egyptian society (Numbers 18:20-21; 1 Timothy 5:17-18).

questions.question: What does Joseph’s management of the famine illustrate about God’s providence?
options: God governs history through human agents to provide salvation and sustenance
God is uninvolved in worldly affairs
Famine is a punishment without any opportunity for grace
Human wisdom alone can solve all crises
questions.correctAnswer: God governs history through human agents to provide salvation and sustenance
questions.explanation: Joseph’s stewardship (Genesis 47:14-23) exemplifies divine providence, where God orchestrates events for salvation, consistent with biblical teaching on God’s sovereign care (Proverbs 21:1; Acts 2:23; Romans 8:28).

questions.question: How does the settlement of Israel in Goshen relate to the broader biblical narrative of salvation history?
options: It prefigures God's covenant faithfulness and the eventual Exodus deliverance
It signifies permanent exile and rejection by God
It marks the end of Israel's identity as a people
It shows the failure of God's promises
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures God's covenant faithfulness and the eventual Exodus deliverance
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:27 shows Israel prospering in Egypt, setting the stage for future deliverance (Exodus 1-12), illustrating God's redemptive plan and covenant faithfulness (Deuteronomy 7:9; Romans 11:29).

questions.question: What is the theological significance of Jacob blessing Pharaoh in this chapter?
options: It demonstrates the extension of God’s covenant blessing beyond Israel to Gentile rulers
It shows Jacob submitting to Egyptian gods
It indicates Pharaoh’s superiority over Israel
It has no theological significance
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates the extension of God’s covenant blessing beyond Israel to Gentile rulers
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:7-10 illustrates Jacob blessing Pharaoh, symbolizing God's universal blessing through Israel, foreshadowing Christ’s mission to the Gentiles (Genesis 12:3; Numbers 24:9; Galatians 3:8).

questions.question: What does Jacob’s request regarding his burial reveal about his faith and hope?
options: He desired to be buried with his ancestors, indicating belief in God's promises about the land and resurrection
He wished to be buried in Egypt to honor Pharaoh
He wanted a grand Egyptian tomb
He had no concern for burial
questions.correctAnswer: He desired to be buried with his ancestors, indicating belief in God's promises about the land and resurrection
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:29-31 shows Jacob asking Joseph to bury him in Canaan, affirming faith in God's covenant promises and foreshadowing resurrection hope (Hebrews 11:13-16; Acts 26:8).

questions.question: What does the phrase 'the days of the years of my pilgrimage' in Jacob's speech most clearly signify?
options: Life as a temporary sojourner on earth awaiting God’s eternal promises
Permanent residence and ownership of the land
A carefree and abundant life
An exile without hope
questions.correctAnswer: Life as a temporary sojourner on earth awaiting God’s eternal promises
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:9 uses 'pilgrimage' to describe life’s transient nature, echoing the biblical theme of believers as strangers on earth looking for a heavenly home (Psalm 39:12; Hebrews 11:13-16; 1 Peter 2:11).

questions.question: How did Joseph’s actions during famine highlight the doctrine of stewardship?
options: By wisely managing resources to sustain many lives under God’s authority
By hoarding wealth for himself
By ignoring the needs of others
By relinquishing control to Pharaoh immediately
questions.correctAnswer: By wisely managing resources to sustain many lives under God’s authority
questions.explanation: Joseph’s management (Genesis 47:12-23) exemplifies stewardship, where God entrusts humans to manage His provisions (Luke 12:42-44; 1 Corinthians 4:2; Colossians 3:23-24).

questions.question: What does Pharaoh’s question to Jacob about his age signify in a theological context?
options: An acknowledgment of Jacob’s long life marked by God’s sustaining grace
Curiosity about his genealogy
Disrespect for Jacob’s age
A test of Jacob’s wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: An acknowledgment of Jacob’s long life marked by God’s sustaining grace
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:8 implies respect and recognition of God’s sustaining power in Jacob’s extended life, consistent with biblical reflections on life as a gift from God (Psalm 90:12; Job 12:10; James 1:17).

questions.question: What does the transformation of Egyptian land ownership during the famine imply about human dependency on God?
options: Human possessions are ultimately subject to God’s sovereign control
Humans can secure their own future without God
Famine has no spiritual significance
Land ownership is permanent and absolute
questions.correctAnswer: Human possessions are ultimately subject to God’s sovereign control
questions.explanation: Genesis 47:20-22 shows the transfer of land to Pharaoh, illustrating that God controls all earthly possessions, a truth echoed in Scripture (Psalm 24:1; Haggai 2:8; James 1:17).

questions.question: In what way does Genesis 47 contribute to the doctrine of salvation history?
options: It demonstrates God’s providential preparation for Israel’s future deliverance
It denies any future redemption for Israel
It focuses only on Egyptian history
It rejects God’s covenant promises
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates God’s providential preparation for Israel’s future deliverance
questions.explanation: Genesis 47 shows God positioning Israel in Egypt in preparation for the Exodus, illustrating His unfolding redemptive plan (Genesis 12:1-3; Exodus 3:7-8; Romans 11:26).
